title: Covered Bowl

  object_colour: multicoloured

  physical_appearance: This is a covered bowl in underglaze blue
 iron red
 and gold. Within the cartouches
 are decorations of flowering plants
 and a carp with its head and tail above the waves. Interspersing the cartouches are scroll motifs and florets. Standing at the top of the lid is a figure of a rooster.

  subject_terms_1: flower (motif)  carp scrolls (motifs) roosters (birds) exports  tableware

  subject_terms_2: Imari porcelain Flowers in art  Leaves in art Exports  Roosters in art  Fishes in art  Tableware

  subject_terms_3: Decorative arts Ceramics

  subject_terms_4: 

  sgcool_label_text: This covered bowl with under-glaze blue
 iron red
 and gold decoration was made at kilns in Arita
 Japan. Porcelain with this combination of colours has come to be called “Imari ware” (after the Japanese port city from which it was exported). These wares became popular in Europe in the late 17th century
 via the trade of the Dutch East India Company. They brought in Japanese ceramics when Chinese production fell because of political instability.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a covered bowl in underglaze blue, iron red, and gold. Within the cartouches, are decorations of flowering plants, and a carp with its head and tail above the waves. Interspersing the cartouches are scroll motifs and florets. Standing at the top of the lid is a figure of a rooster.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: This covered bowl with under-glaze blue, iron red, and gold decoration was made at kilns in Arita, Japan. Porcelain with this combination of colours has come to be called “Imari ware” (after the Japanese port city from which it was exported). These wares became popular in Europe in the late 17th century, via the trade of the Dutch East India Company. They brought in Japanese ceramics when Chinese production fell because of political instability.
